awd_titl_txt: DMREF: SusChEM: Collaborative Research:  Rapid Design of Earth Abundant Inorganic Materials for Future PVs
awd_abstract_narration:
DMREF: SusChEM: Rapid Design of Earth Abundant Inorganic Materials for Future PVs

Non-technical Description: Electricity is on of the fastest growing sectors in the U.S. and the worldwide demand for electricity is also on a rapid rise. For many countries, their economic growth is dependent on finding low-cost and readily available supply of electricity. Identification of new earth-abundant semiconductors along with their optoelectronic properties and low-cost processing technology in this project will influence how future thin-film photovoltaics (PV) are fabricated. The successful research outcome of the project will contrbute toward widespread use of PV as an abundant source of electricity for a sustainable energy economy in the U.S. as well as the rest of the world. The integrative nature of the research and education will train and co-mentor graduate and undergraduate students in cross-disciplinary skills that are essential for developing innovative solutions as they join the workplace and contribute to the U.S. leadership in the burgeoning field of energy. 

Technical Description: This project will develop the fundamental scientific knowledge that will lead to the identification and large-scale use of new semiconducting materials composed of earth-abundant elements for photovoltaics (PV). The central aspect of the project is a close coupling among all three of its research thrusts to: (1) conduct rapid search and rational design of promising earth-abundant materials through computational screening using first principles calculations; (2) synthesize promising materials by solution phase providing exquisite control through chemistry and to measure their material and optoelectronic properties; and (3) fabricate functioning solar cells and develop scientific relationship between the properties estimated from the first principles and device performance contributing toward 'inverse designs' of material for electronic applications. An ongoing feedback among computational estimates and experimentally measured material and electronic properties will allow refinement of the methods in all three research thrusts leading to rapid screening of large number of materials from a vast search space. Project efforts will identify the most promising earth-abundant materials for high efficiency solar cells.

por.por_cntn:
This DMREF grant has allowed us to survey a number of next-generation, earth-abundant materials that could be used to directly convert heat or sunlight into electricity from both computational and experimental perspectives. We eliminated many candidate materials through computation because their properties were not adequate. Several of the promising inorganic chalcogenide semiconductors were successfully synthesized by developing a versatile chemistry of dissolution of an array of metals and their chalcogens in amine-thiol solvents. 

Enargite (Cu3AsS4) is one such material that we found to be an ideal candidate for photovoltaic applications due to its high absorption coefficient, long carrier lifetimes, and bandgap of 1.42 eV, which is in the ideal range for photovoltaic materials. Three unique and novel methods were developed to synthesize phase pure enargite films: a vacuum-processed approach which involved thermal evaporation and heat treatment in a carbon free environment, a nanoparticle approach which involved the synthesis of Cu3AsS4 nanoparticles that were then coated onto substrates, and a novel molecular precursor approach which involved the reactive dissolution of metal chalcogenides using the versatile amine-thiol solution chemistry to create inks that could directly be coated onto substrates. Using these methods, our group fabricated the first photovoltaic devices with large-grained enargite absorber layers. Optoelectronic characterization done on these enargite films at Purdue and with collaborators at Drexel University determined Shockley-Read-Hall recombination lifetimes to be greater than 1.4 ns. This represents a promising initial benchmark for the enargite material.  

Sinnerite (Cu6As4S9) is another ideal candidate for photovoltaic materials that we studied. We synthesized the first pure polycrystalline sinnerite (Cu6As4S9) thin films and performed optoelectronic characterization to evaluate its potential for use in photovoltaic applications.

We partnered with Argonne and Brookhaven National Labs to study the amine-thiol solvent system and developed a benign solvent route for fabrication of metal chalcogenide thin films applicable to a variety of systems including, but not limited to, Cu3AsS4, CuInGa(S,Se)2, and lead chalcogenides. We have developed a versatile synthesis route using the metal thiolate complexes created from amine-thiol solution chemistry for the synthesis of an array of metal chalcogenide nanoparticles. Furthermore, PbS, PbSe, and PbTe particles ranging in size from a few nanometers to micrometers could be synthesized with exquisite control of shape at room temperature. This scalable solution chemistry was combined with newly developed lab scale slot dye coaters and automated blade coaters created from modified 3D printers to create reproducible and high quality thin-film solar cells that can be scaled for mass production in industry. 

Throughout the course of the project, we supplemented our experimental work with computational studies. For enargite, we identified types of defects, their formation energies, and their locations within the band gap using density functional theory (DFT) calculations. We then experimentally verified these results through low temperature photoluminescence experiments. Collaborative results demonstrate a low defect concentration in Cu3AsS4, proving that it is a promising absorber material for photovoltaic applications. DFT studies showed that the dominant defect in enargite is Cu vacancies (VCu). A novel surface searching algorithm created to study the surface structures of enargite suggests the formation energies of VCu decrease from bulk to surface, potentially explaining the trap-band transition side peak seen in photoluminescence spectra for enargite and the material’s high carrier concentration. Deep level defects that could have more detrimental impacts on the efficiency of enargite based solar cells were found to have large formation energies, making these defects unlikely to form.

Every year, students in the DMREF project engaged in outreach activities aimed at inspiring the next generation of STEM scholars by teaching science to elementary and middle school students through interactive lessons including building and racing solar cars. Graduate students in the DMREF project also had opportunities to utilize facilities and interact with scientists at various national labs and presented their work at a variety of conferences including the Materials Research Society (MRS) Conference and the IEEE Photovoltaics Specialists Conference (PVSC). Some of our students have won prestigious awards at these conferences for their research and presentation skills. These opportunities to exhibit their work and network has helped prepare students in the DMREF project for careers in both academia and industry.
